close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (definition) / type returned by MHD_get_master
explanation:
You must know the exact types/prototypes/definitions to decide whether any pointer parameters in calculate_add_nonce_with_retry could/should be const (MISRA: prefer pointers to const when possible). For each symbol:

- struct MHD_Connection (definition): determine which fields of the pointed-to object are accessed or modified by this function (e.g. connection->daemon) and to see whether any operations in this function mutate the connection object. If the function never mutates the MHD_Connection state, the pointee could be const.

- struct MHD_Daemon (definition) / type returned by MHD_get_master: connection->daemon is read to access fields (digest_auth_rand_size, nonce_nc_size). You need the daemon structure to confirm those fields are not modified and to check types used by logging and other callees.

- MHD_get_master (prototype): it is called with connection->daemon; its parameter/return types determine whether reading connection->daemon requires a non-const pointer or not (i.e. whether passing a const pointer would be compatible).

- MHD_DLOG (prototype / macro): called with MHD_get_master(...).prototype/constness of its daemon parameter matters: if it takes a non-const daemon pointer this may prevent making connection->daemon (and thus connection) const in this function.

- calculate_add_nonce (prototype): this function is invoked with connection. If calculate_add_nonce requires a non-const struct MHD_Connection * (i.e. it mutates the connection), then calculate_add_nonce_with_retry cannot change its parameter to point-to-const. You must inspect the callee signature to know whether the local pointer could be a pointer-to-const.

- struct DigestAlgorithm (definition): the function reads da->hashing and calls digest_reset(da). The digest type definition helps determine which operations modify the digest state and whether da must remain a non-const pointer.

- digest_get_size (prototype): to see whether it accepts a const DigestAlgorithm *; if it does, that supports constness, but digest_reset (below) may still require non-const.

- digest_reset (prototype): this clearly mutates digest state; its signature confirms that da must be a non-const pointer (precludes making da const).

- digest_ext_error (prototype) (guarded by MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR): used conditionally; its parameter constness affects whether da could be const in contexts where this macro is enabled.

- NONCE_STD_LEN (macro) and MAX_DIGEST (macro): used to size nonce buffers and to compute memcpy lengths. These do not directly affect pointer constness but are needed to verify how nonce (destination) is used (it is written), so nonce must be non-const. Include these macros so the analyzer can confirm that nonce is written to and thus cannot be const.

- DAUTH_JUMPBACK_MAX (macro): used to adjust timestamp2; not directly pointer related but included to fully understand the manipulation paths that may affect whether re-try calls alter any pointees.

- strlen (prototype): used on realm (const char *). Its prototype documents that realm is read-only (const), confirming realm's const qualification is appropriate.

- memcpy (prototype): used to write into nonce (destination) from nonce2 (source). Its signature (dest pointer non-const, src const) shows nonce is modified and therefore must not be const.

Collectively these symbols let the next analyst determine (a) whether calculate_add_nonce_with_retry itself modifies any of the objects pointed to by its pointer parameters, (b) whether any callees require non-const pointers (preventing adding const), and (c) whether some pointer parameters are already correctly const or could be more strictly const-qualified per MISRA.
